titleproper.value: Guide to the Dorothy Gallagher Research Files on Carlo Tresca <num>TAM.117</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-09T19:56:25</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Dorothy Gallagher Research Files on Carlo Tresca

abstract.value: Carlo Tresca (1897-1943), a charismatic Italian-born anarchist, labor agitator and newspaper editor, was one of the most fascinating figures of the American Left prior to World War II. Dorothy Gallagher, a New York City-based freelance writer is the author of All the Right Enemies: The Life and Murder of Carlo Tresca (Rutgers University Press, 1988). The collection consists of Gallagher's subject files, interview notes and research notes created in preparation for publication of her book.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Dorothy Gallagher Research Files on Carlo Tresca; TAM 117; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Dorothy Gallagher, 2004. The accession number associated with this gift is 2004.017.

<list><item>Gallagher, Dorothy, All the Right Enemies: The Life and Murder of Carlo Tresca. New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press, 1988.</item><item>Pernicone, Nunzio, Carlo Tresca: Portrait of a Rebel. New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005.</item></list>

The collection also contains copies of correspondence obtained by Gallagher from various archives and collections. Of special note are letters to and from Margaret De Silver, John Dos Passos, Herbert Solow, and Hannah Green, and correspondence between Harry Weinberger and Tresca, dating from 1938.

subject.value: Children |x Institutional care |z Europe |v Pictorial works.
World War, 1939-1945 |x Civilian relief |v Pictorial works.
